name: Hyperledger Explorer
description:
Hyperledger Explorer is a simple, powerful, easy-to-use, highly maintainable, open
source browser for viewing activity on the underlying blockchain network. Users
have the ability to configure & build Hyperledger Explorer natively on macOS and
Ubuntu.
interact_justification: All contributors are welcomed, please read on how to [CONTRIBUTE](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
contribution_justification:
Non-trivial contribution file in [repository](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged in [documentation](https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/).
contribution_requirements_justification:
Please see [CONTRIBUTING](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) to Hyperledger Explorer document, and 
[Coding guidelines](https://blockchain-explorer.readthedocs.io/en/master/Style-guides/js-style.html)
license_location_justification: Non-trivial [license](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/LICENSE).
floss_license_justification:
Hyperledger Explorer Project source code is released under the Apache 2.0 license.  The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
For more [info](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/LICENSE). The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Hyperledger Explorer [documentation](https://blockchain-explorer.readthedocs.io/en/master/index.html), and [README](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README.md)
documentation_interface_justification: Swagger/OpenAPI is provided and instructions how to invoke described in [document](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer#140-hyperledger-explorer-swagger----).
repo_public_justification:
Mirror Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs. [Source control
via GitHub](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer)
repo_track_justification:
Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they
were made. [Source control via GitHub](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer) Repository on GitHub, which uses
git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made. Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Mirror repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed. Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: The project uses Git tags, see [change log](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md)
release_notes_vulns_justification: If any known vulnerability was fixed, it is described in for example, https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/release_notes/v0.3.8.md#known-vulnerabilities
build_common_tools_justification: Use of NPM, and tasks configured in ["scripts" of](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/package.json)
test_justification:
The project include a comprehensive unit and [integration test suite](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer#170-testing----) configured at:
   [Selenium test](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/client/e2e-setup.sh), and
   [BDD test](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/client/test/E2E-TEST-README.md) and are triggered during the CI/CD builds.
 - Code coverage is setup in both [frontend](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/client/package.json#L58) and [back-end](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/test/package.json#L24).

 - [Coverage report example](https://dev.azure.com/Hyperledger/blockchain-explorer) available after each Azure Pipeline build, see Code Coverage tab
test_invocation_justification: Yes. npm run test, part of main.sh script, and tasks configured in ["scripts" of](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/package.json)
test_most_justification: Linting is part of git commit. test runs are part of main.sh test
tests_are_added_justification: Build status generated after each Azure Pipeline [build](https://dev.azure.com/Hyperledger/blockchain-explorer)
tests_documented_added_justification: Build status generated after each Azure Pipeline [build](https://dev.azure.com/Hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/)
warnings_justification: In ECMAScript modules, which always have strict mode semantics, the directives "use strict" is not required, a task "precommit": "lint-staged" runs with every commit, [see](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/package.json#L84)
warnings_fixed_justification: a variety of static analysis tools and linters are applied on each change request and each merge commit as a function of CI
warnings_strict_justification: In ECMAScript modules, which always have strict mode semantics, the directives "use strict" is not required, a task "precommit": "lint-staged" runs with every commit, [see](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/package.json#L84)
know_common_errors_justification: Vinita Chinoy is certified in OWASP
delivery_mitm_justification: Project uses JSON Web Token (JWT), https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7519.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: Vulnerabilities are fixed within 60 days or less
static_analysis_justification: A eslint task "precommit" runs with every commit, [see](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/package.json), thais is configured in blockchain-explorer/.eslintrc.json)
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: A eslint task "precommit" runs with every commit, [see](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/package.json), thais is configured in blockchain-explorer/.eslintrc.json
dynamic_analysis_justification: Dynamic code analysis was scanned by ZAP tool, HLExplorer doesn't use cookies
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: All vulnerabilities found by the audit are fixed within timeline. See [more](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/security/policy)
discussion_justification:
[Jira](https://jira.hyperledger.org/projects/BE/issues)

[Hyperledger Explorer Chat](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer)

[Hyperledger Explorer Discussion Group](https://lists.hyperledger.org/g/explorer)
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

name: Tau
description: GTK frontend for the xi text editor, written in Rust
interact_justification: Currently https://gxi.cogitri.dev only contains docs, which are automatically generated.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: gxi is currently a rather small project, but I shall add that.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/Cogitri/gxi/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://gxi.cogitri.dev
documentation_interface_justification: gxi is binary only, so there is no external interface
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/Cogitri/gxi/blob/master/Changelog.md>.
report_responses_justification: https://github.com/Cogitri/gxi/issues, about every bug is answered within days
build_justification: It offers cargo for building the Rust code and Meson to also build the resources
build_common_tools_justification: Meson is very common in the GNOME space, cargo is _the_ build tool for RUst
build_floss_tools_justification: All dependencies and tools are OSS
test_justification: It uses Rust's test suite and might use gtk-test soon.
test_most_justification: gxi should get tests soon, but gtk-test is a bit hard to use.
warnings_justification: It uses Rust's warnings and also runs clippy on CI
warnings_strict_justification: It uses clippy in a very aggressive setting.
delivery_mitm_justification: The github releases should at least include sha256 sums
static_analysis_fixed_justification: No CVEs have been found yet.
static_analysis_often_justification: Clippy is run for every commit on CI
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: It uses Drone and Travis CI
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: The docs on https://gxi.cogitri.dev are in English, as is the entire code and the GitHub page.
hardened_site_justification: // One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing.

name: OpenSwitch (OPX)
description: The OpenSwitch(OPX) platform is an open source, Linux-based network operating system (NOS) for disaggregated switches built around OCP-compliant hardware, utilizing an open network installation environment (ONIE) boot loader.  OPX supports a rich set of L2/L3 networking features that are compatible with a wide variety of 10G, 25G, 40G and 100G hardware platforms from multiple vendors.
sites_https_justification:
https://www.openswitch.net/
Application is downloaded via apt-get.
contribution_justification: https://github.com/open-switch/opx-docs/wiki/Contributor-guide
license_location_justification: https://github.com/open-switch/opx-docs/wiki/Repositories  List of repositories and each repo has readme and license (copyright) files.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://github.com/open-switch/opx-docs/wiki
repo_public_justification:
Code repositories
* [https://github.com/open-switch](https://github.com/open-switch) 
    * 59 public repositories 
    * Provides a list of all OPX repositories which are mapped to architecture components
        * [https://github.com/open-switch/opx-docs/wiki/Repositories](https://github.com/open-switch/opx-docs/wiki/Repositories)
repo_track_justification: All source code is hosted on github for code version management.
repo_interim_justification:
Code review
    * OPX uses the Github Pull Request interface for code review
    * Overview of code review norms, practices, conventions, rules.
    * To what extent are external/private code review systems used? None
Continuous Integration tooling
* CodeFactor
* BuildKite, whose pipeline consists of:
    * Setup
        * Docker Hub
    * Build
        * dbp
    * Smoketest
        * Docker Hub
        * AWS
    * Github DCO
repo_distributed_justification: hosted on github. https://github.com/open-switch
version_unique_justification: Each new release is numbered and incremented. Current Release 3.1.0 (December 2018)
version_tags_justification: Versions are tagged in the repositories.
report_tracker_justification: Go to issues in respective Github repositories.
report_archive_justification: Issue tracker is available and public: https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+user%3Aopen-switch+sort%3Aupdated-desc
vulnerability_report_process_justificati:
https://github.com/open-switch/opx-docs/wiki/Report-bugs  has an email that you can report vulnerabilities. 

To report and discuss security issues, you can send an email to security@lists.openswitch.net.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati:
The security group receives the venerability reports to a private list and can make determination on how to publish it. 
https://github.com/open-switch/opx-docs/wiki/Report-bugs
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerabilities reported to establish response baseline.
build_justification: The project provides a working build system via a Docker container and build scripts. Refer to the “opx-build” repository and its README for more information.
build_common_tools_justification: Common tools are used for building the software. Generally, each repository uses a “Debian-style” build and Makefile/script infrastructure.
build_floss_tools_justification: The project is buildable using only FLOSS tools. See previous responses.
test_justification: Our automated test suite is published in the “opx-test” repository. The test framework is written in Ansible and Python.
test_invocation_justification: The test suite is invokable in a standard way for Ansible.
test_most_justification: The test suite covers the “master” code branch, and it consists largely of functional tests.
test_policy_justification: The project does have an informal general policy that major new functionality should be accounted for in the automated test suite in the “opx-test” repository.
tests_are_added_justification: A recent example is when new scripts were recently written in the “opx-tools” repo, tests for those scripts were also added to the “opx-test” repo. You can see the PR that is about to merge: https://github.com/open-switch/opx-test/pull/25
tests_documented_added_justification: The tests are being added in practice, but the policy isn’t documented anywhere AFAIK.
warnings_justification: This should be evident in each component repository’s Makefile.am in flags like COMMON_HARDEN_FLAGS, C_HARDEN_FLAGS, and LD_HARDEN_FLAGS.
warnings_strict_justification: We feel that we are maximally strict with warnings where practical.
know_secure_design_justification: Several OPX Developers are trained on secure software development practices.
crypto_published_justification: Cryptographic protocols and algorithms are not used in the software produced by the project. Where applicable, the OPX operating system relies on the standard applications provided by the underlying Debian distribution to provide cryptographic protocols and algorithms (e.g., OpenSSH, OpenSSL, etc.).
delivery_mitm_justification: we use https for and github for download resources.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: here are no unpatched publicly known vulnerabilities in our software project.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: If/when vulnerabilities are reported, we will fix them rapidly.
static_analysis_justification: CodeFactor is run against all pull-requests
static_analysis_often_justification: CodeFactor is run against all pull-requests
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Continuous integration is implemented using Buildkite. You can see that it is run on each pull-request.
discussion_justification: https://chat.openswitch.net for live chat and discussion with the developer community. Weekly TSC calls ( https://github.com/open-switch/opx-docs/wiki/Technical-Steering-Committee-Meeting-Details). Community mailing lists (https://lists.openswitch.net)
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
dco_justification:
https://github.com/open-switch/opx-docs/wiki/Contributor-guide
Status checks must pass for a review to be merged. Here are a few status checks:

Code-Review — A maintainer of the repository must approve your changes
CI Build — Your change must successfully build
DCO Signoff — You must sign all commits
documentation_quick_start_justification: https://github.com/open-switch/opx-docs/wiki/Install-OPX-on-Dell-EMC-ON-Series-platforms. There is also VM version for developers to setup working sandboxes.
sites_password_security_justification: website is managed in multi-tenant wordpress environment, repos are all hosted in github and follow github authentication models.

https://opensource.org/licenses/Apache-2.0 The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://www.orekit.org/site-orekit-development/index.html
repo_public_justification: https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit.git
repo_track_justification: https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/commits/develop
repo_interim_justification:
All revisions and releases are public:
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/releases
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit.git
repo_distributed_justification: git : https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit.git
release_notes_vulns_justification: Only one security flaw - which could lead to the unavailability of the service - has been identified since the beginning of the project. The development team had requested a CVE number, but never obtained it.
enhancement_responses_justification: 40 of the 56 enhancements (71 %) and 14 of the 27 (52 %) features requested in the last 12 months have been implemented.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati:
The way to report vulnerabilities (i.e. security issues) is described in the project's README file:
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/blob/develop/README.md
vulnerability_report_private_justificati:
An issue can be marked as confidential ("[ ] This issue is confidential and should only be visible to team members with at least Reporter access.")
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/issues
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerabilities (i.e. security issues) have been reported in the last 6 months, but those that have been reported previously were fixed in less than 3 days and a patch version was released immediately after.
build_justification:
Maven is used to compile sources, generate documentation and binary packages.
Continuous integration is provided by Gitlab CI. A pipeline is triggered each time a changeset is received.
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/pipelines
build_floss_tools_justification:
All required dependencies and tools are FLOSS:
Hipparchus : https://www.hipparchus.org/
JUnit : https://junit.org/
Maven : http://maven.apache.org/
OpenJDK : https://openjdk.java.net/
test_justification:
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/pipelines
Tests are included in the project repository (in src/test directory)
test_policy_justification:
Automated tests are required. A test coverage rate of 95% is desired.
https://sonar.orekit.org/dashboard?id=orekit%3Aorekit
tests_are_added_justification:
Quality analysis is carried out continuously via the SonarQube software. Continuous integration launches the quality analysis on all branches.
https://sonar.orekit.org/dashboard?id=orekit%3Aorekit
tests_documented_added_justification:
https://www.orekit.org/site-orekit-development/guidelines.html
"The first goal, validation, implies tests must be as extensive as possible. They should include realistic operational cases but also contingency cases. The jacoco tool must be used to monitor test coverage. A very high level of coverage is desired. We do not set up mandatory objective figures, but only guidelines here. However, a 60% line coverage would clearly not be acceptable at all and 80% would be considered deceptive."
warnings_justification: Several tools are used: CheckStyle, SpotBugs, SonarQube, etc.
warnings_fixed_justification:
SonarQube's qualimetric report speaks for itself:
https://sonar.orekit.org/dashboard?id=orekit%3Aorekit
warnings_strict_justification:
SonarQube's qualimetric report speaks for itself:
https://sonar.orekit.org/dashboard?id=orekit%3Aorekit
know_secure_design_justification: The design and code quality of Orekit proves that the team knows the best coding practices, and a committer monitors the vulnerabilities affecting Java and the associated tools (he already reported two vulnerabilities affecting Orekit, these vulnerabilities were quickly corrected).
know_common_errors_justification: One of the main developers keeps informed of the vulnerabilities discovered in Java and checks if they are relevant in the context of Orekit. If necessary, he opens a private issue so that the team can consider a patch and a security release like this: https://www.orekit.org/news/2017/11/06/orekit-security-fix.html
delivery_mitm_justification:
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/releases
https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.orekit/orekit
A GnuPG signature is provided for eache source and binary archive
delivery_unsigned_justification:
https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.orekit/orekit
SHA1 MD5 sums and a GnuPG signature are provided for all source and binary archives
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat:
Vulnerabilities are quickly corrected, a security release is provided for each maintained version of Orekit and they are publicly announced:
https://www.orekit.org/news/2017/11/06/orekit-security-fix.html
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: The security issues that have been reported previously were fixed in less than 3 days and a patch version was released immediately after.
static_analysis_justification: CheckStyle, SpotBugs and SonarQube are used and run by the continuous integration: https://sonar.orekit.org/dashboard?id=orekit%3Aorekit
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: SpotBugs includes a lot of security checks
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Developers monitor SonarQube reports and promptly fix any serious issues reported.
static_analysis_often_justification: SpotBugs analysis is included in our CI process and run on every changeset.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Orekit is a Java library. This language supports memory accesses and guarantees their consistency.
discussion_justification: https://forum.orekit.org/
no_leaked_credentials_justification: No private key is included in the source code repository and all sensitive variables handled by continuous integration (tokens, login/password pairs) are masked by configuration. Cf. Gitlab CI documentation: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/variables/#mask-a-cicd-variable
hardening_justification: The Orekit project aims to provide a low-level computing library with a very small attack surface. However, the development team takes care of the robustness of the code and has a very high level of requirement on its quality and on the test coverage. Some tests have been specially developed to verify the numerical stability of the algorithms.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification:
Orekit is a library available in the official Maven repository:
https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.orekit/orekit
and in our own package repository:
https://packages.orekit.org/#browse/browse:maven-releases:org%2Forekit%2Forekit
Thanks to Maven, projects using the Orekit library can download and deploy this library with their application.
dco_justification:
It is written in the governance of the project that the acceptance of contributions is subject to the prior signature by the contributor of an ICLA (Individual Contributor License Agreement) and a CCLA (Corporate Contributor License Agreement):
https://www.orekit.org/doc/orekit_governance_v4.pdf
governance_justification:
This is indicated in the governance of the project.
https://www.orekit.org/doc/orekit_governance_v4.pdf
code_of_conduct_justification: A code of conduct is desirable for any project, but the Orekit project has not yet encountered any inappropriate behavior or remarks that has made it feel necessary to establish such a code.
roles_responsibilities_justification:
This is indicated in the governance of the project.
https://www.orekit.org/doc/orekit_governance_v4.pdf
access_continuity_justification:
Several people have the ability (access and skills) to administer the collaborative development tools we use. The cryptographic keys used to sign the archives are not personal keys, but project-specific keys that several administrators can use. Releases can be done by several people (and it is not always the same person who does the release). The releasing process is fully documented:
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/blob/develop/src/site/markdown/release-guide.md
bus_factor_justification:
Several people have the ability (access and skills) to administer the collaborative development tools we use. The cryptographic keys used to sign the archives are not personal keys, but project-specific keys that several administrators can use. Releases can be done by several people (and it is not always the same person who does the release). The releasing process is fully documented:
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/blob/develop/src/site/markdown/release-guide.md
documentation_current_justification:
The documentation is included in the source code repository, maintained along with the code (providing up-to-date feature documentation is a project requirement) and automatically built and released with the code.
https://www.orekit.org/doc-maven.html
https://www.orekit.org/site-orekit-development/index.html
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: This problem is not taken into account by the team, which has limited human resources to develop a software implementing the state of the art in its field and which addresses a niche market (space dynamics).
internationalization_justification:
https://www.orekit.org/site-orekit-development/index.html
Orekit is localized in several languages: Danish, English, French, Galician, German, Greek, Italian, Norwegian, Romanian and Spanish.
sites_password_security_justification: The project relies on a static web site and a few collaborative development tools (Gitlab, SonarQube, Nexus, Discourse) that implement best practices in this domain.
maintenance_or_update_justification:
When critical issues occur, the project releases patches for several versions:
https://www.orekit.org/news/2017/11/06/orekit-security-fix.html
But less severe bugs are only fixed on the version under development and on the last stable version released:
https://www.orekit.org/news/2021/06/17/orekit-10.3.1-released.html
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio:
This feature is provided by Gitlab:
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/issues
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: Vulnerabilities (i.e. security issues) are very rare (only 2 have been identified since 2008) and Gitlab warns developers that the reported issue is confidential.
coding_standards_justification:
https://www.orekit.org/site-orekit-development/guidelines.html
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/blob/develop/checkstyle.xml
The Orekit project is one of the reference projects used by CheckStyle developers to verify the impact of new rules and developments.
The CI pipeline verifies the application of these coding rules.
coding_standards_enforced_justification:
This is documented in the contributing guide (how to configure the Eclipse IDE to take into account the CheckStyle rules):
https://www.orekit.org/site-orekit-development/contributing.html
build_standard_variables_justification: The project provides a Java library, which is not a native binary, but contains a bytecode.
build_preserve_debug_justification: This feature is provided by Java compiler.
build_non_recursive_justification: This requirement is managed by Maven.
installation_standard_variables_justific: Java applications does not follow the POSIX standard, but Java and Maven ensure a homogeneity of deployment between Java applications.
external_dependencies_justification:
This feature is provided by Maven and dependencies are listed in the generated documentation:
https://www.orekit.org/site-orekit-development/project-info.html
dependency_monitoring_justification:
The Orekit library has only one external dependency. This is the Hipparchus library, which is developed by the same people:
https://www.hipparchus.org/
interfaces_current_justification: The Orekit library is a low level library. It only relies on the Hipparchus library, which is developed by the same people. The Orekit library is one of the reference implementations of several standards in its field.
test_policy_mandated_justification:
https://www.orekit.org/site-orekit-development/guidelines.html
"The first goal, validation, implies tests must be as extensive as possible. They should include realistic operational cases but also contingency cases. The jacoco tool must be used to monitor test coverage. A very high level of coverage is desired. We do not set up mandatory objective figures, but only guidelines here. However, a 60% line coverage would clearly not be acceptable at all and 80% would be considered deceptive."
input_validation_justification: The reading of the data is carefully validated in the source code. For this reason and others, Orekit is one of the reference implementations of several standards in its field.
signed_releases_justification:
SHA1 and MD5 sums, and GnuPG signature are provided for each artefact:
https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/orekit/orekit/10.3.1/
This is not internally documented as these tools are widely used for this purpose.
contributors_unassociated_justification:
As described on the project homepage, Orekit has an open governance and its project management committee (PMC) is composed of 9 different entities. To date (nov. 2021), the project has 5 external committers, who do not work for CS GROUP, the company that created Orekit. One of them has already piloted a release of the project.
https://www.orekit.org/
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/graphs/develop
copyright_per_file_justification:
The copyright header template - which specifies the copyright holder and the license - is provided and CheckStyle checks for the presence of this header in the source code files.
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/blob/develop/license-header.txt
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/blob/develop/pom.xml
license_per_file_justification:
The copyright header template - which specifies the copyright holder and the license - is provided and CheckStyle checks for the presence of this header in the source code files.
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/blob/develop/license-header.txt
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/blob/develop/pom.xml
code_review_standards_justification:
The Orekit project has very strong requirements on the quality of the code, on the provision of automated tests and adequate documentation. The quality is supervised on a continuous basis via SonarQube. In addition, the project favors merge requests (MR) in Gitlab.
https://sonar.orekit.org/dashboard?id=orekit%3Aorekit
https://www.orekit.org/site-orekit-latest/guidelines.html
https://www.orekit.org/site-orekit-latest/contributing.html
two_person_review_justification:
The project favors merge requests (MR) in Gitlab:
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/merge_requests?scope=all&state=all
maintained_justification:
The Orekit project is maintained by a dedicated team of CS GROUP – France, which receives numerous external contributions from companies, national agencies and research centers in the space field. The project has several external committers.
https://gitlab.orekit.org/orekit/orekit/-/commits/develop

name: Adélie Linux
description: Adélie Linux is a Free, Libre operating environment based on the Linux kernel. We aim for standards compliance, compatibility with a wide variety of computers, and ease of use without sacrificing features, setting us apart from other Linux distributions.
contribution_justification: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/packages/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst - pull requests or send via mailing list, both described in detail.
contribution_requirements_justification: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/packages/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst links to the Developer's Handbook at https://help.adelielinux.org/html/devel/ which describes packaging in detail.
license_location_justification: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/packages/blob/master/LICENSE
floss_license_justification: The package recipes themselves are NCSA.  We only allow libre software to be packaged; if it isn't on SPDX, it isn't accepted. The NCSA license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: Many of the MIT derivatives are not OSI-approved, and there are a few licenses that are uncommon but used by packages that remain libre. The NCSA license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://help.adelielinux.org/
documentation_interface_justification: The packaging format itself is included with abuild as https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/abuild/blob/master/APKBUILD.5 - all packages that have this documentation are built with it included in -doc packages.
repo_public_justification: Packages, base files, and all other relevant software is all tracked in a publicly-accessible, hosted GitLab instance: https://code.foxkit.us/groups/adelie
repo_track_justification: Git does this.
repo_interim_justification: Every package change is tracked in a separate commit, except batch changes (like typo correction, changing HTTP URLs to HTTPS, etc).
repo_distributed_justification: Git is used.
version_unique_justification: Detailed information about our release process is forthcoming; we plan on using SemVer-style versioning.
version_tags_justification: All releases are tagged in their respective repositories.  The packages.git repository is tagged with the overall distribution version (1.0-beta2, for example).
release_notes_justification: Release notes are provided for every release on our blog, https://adelie.blog/ - these are additionally posted to our main Web site.
report_process_justification: Issues may be reported using the issue tracker at https://bts.adelielinux.org/ or the mailing lists at https://lists.adelielinux.org/postorius/lists/
report_responses_justification: Approximately 80% of bugs have been triaged.
enhancement_responses_justification: Most enhancement requests have been requests for packages; most reasonable requests are handled within two weeks.
report_archive_justification: Both our issue tracker and mailing lists would qualify: https://bts.adelielinux.org/ and https://lists.adelielinux.org/postorius/lists/
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: The sec-bugs email alias as discussed at https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/packages/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.rst is for private vulnerability reports.
build_justification: The abuild system is used to build packages and is available as the 'abuild' package in the distribution, or https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/abuild
build_common_tools_justification: The abuild system is written in Bourne shell, with a replacement forthcoming that is written in pure Python 3.
build_floss_tools_justification: abuild is released under the MIT and GPL-2 licenses: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/abuild
test_justification:
abuild has its own test suite: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/abuild/tree/master/tests

Each package that we ship that has a test suite as part of its distribution has that test suite run as part of the packaging process.  If the test suite fails, we are alerted and must fix the issue before the package can be shipped.  In some cases, test suites fail due to upstream issues: this is noted with `options="!check"` in the build recipe.  A reason is required.
test_invocation_justification: `make check` for abuild, `abuild check` for packages (also run as part of the normal `abuild` process).
test_most_justification: // More tests need to be written.
test_policy_justification: // This is being looked in to, but has not been fully implemented yet.
warnings_justification:
`sh -e` is used: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/abuild/blob/master/abuild.in#L1
`checkbashisms` is also being used.
warnings_fixed_justification: We are integrating changes that remove dependence on bash-specific features.
know_secure_design_justification: The Project Lead, A. Wilcox, is familiar with security best practices and has worked to close multiple CVEs in other projects, including packages that are shipped in Adélie Linux.
crypto_published_justification: `abuild` uses SHA-512 for checksumming and `openssl` for package signing.
crypto_call_justification: `abuild` uses `openssl` and `sha512sum`; it does NOT implement its own cryptography.
crypto_floss_justification: All cryptography libraries and software used are fully libre.
crypto_keylength_justification: The default key size for package signing is RSA 2048: https://code.foxkit.us/adelie/abuild/blob/efc6792/abuild-keygen.in#L53
crypto_working_justification: RSA 2048 keys for package signing, SHA-512 for checksumming.
delivery_mitm_justification: Packages are synced to mirrors using rsync over SSH.  Each architecture builder has its own SSH key that can be revoked in the event of a breach..
delivery_unsigned_justification: Package metadata is always verified with RSA 2048 signature verification.  Additionally, package metadata is sent over HTTPS by default.  If the user forces HTTP, the signature verification step is still performed.  (It is possible, though severely warned against, to defeat this using apk's `--allow-untrusted` parameter.)
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: As far as we are aware, there are no unpatched vulnerabilities in any of our produced projects.  We do not yet have a way to determine that for every package we ship.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: The last critical vulnerability was fixed in under 12 hours after being reported.  https://adelie.blog/2018/09/14/urgent-security-patch-for-all-systems-running-adelie-linux/
static_analysis_justification: We are looking in to Coverity for the C packages that we are responsible for (Shimmy, abuild tools).  This has not materialised yet.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: No static analysis tools are used yet.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: No static analysis tools are used yet.
static_analysis_often_justification: No static analysis tools are used yet.
dynamic_analysis_justification: // We have not yet looked in to dynamic analysis tools for our C-based projects.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: // As above, we have not yet looked in to dynamic analysis tools for our C-based projects.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: // As above, we have not yet looked in to dynamic analysis tools for our C-based projects.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: // As above, we have not yet looked in to dynamic analysis tools for our C-based projects.
discussion_justification:
Issue tracker: https://bts.adelielinux.org/
Mailing lists: https://lists.adelielinux.org/postorius/lists/
english_justification: All of our documentation is in English, and all of our bug wranglers can read English.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

name: BSIA

name: pki-lint
description: Bash wrapper for X.509 certificate linting and PKI validation.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: Contributions must not produce any new warnings or errors when checked by automated source code linting tools used by the project. Shell scripts are checked by Shellcheck (https://www.shellcheck.net).
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/rwbaumg/pki-lint/blob/github/LICENSE.md>.
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
// No appropriate folder found for documentation basics.
See README.md and NOTES.md files. More documentation will be added later.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: Git tags used for all releases.
release_notes_vulns_justification: All security related changes will appear in the release notes, and any bugs in third-party dependencies will be either documented, fixed, reported upstream or all of the above.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: The standard bug tracker is used for security-related issues, and can be found at https://github.com/rwbaumg/pki-lint/issues/new
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: Private vulnerability reports are not supported for this project.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: Security related issues are taken seriously, and receive priority over any other issues.
test_invocation_justification: Both the standard Makefile and included build script enable running included source code tests.
test_most_justification: This requirement is an ongoing process; currently only basic source code linting checks are performed. In the future, tests for individual code branches will be added to the automated test suite.
test_policy_justification:
Automated source code tests are run during continuous integration after every commit.
For specific features, it is requested that specific tests be included wherever possible.
tests_are_added_justification: The test policy for this project is implicit - automated logging during CI can be used to validate adherence to testing policies unless or until another mechanism is formally adopted.
tests_documented_added_justification: As this project is itself a testing framework, documentation for testing the project itself is not currently a high priority.
know_secure_design_justification: Project owner is a senior information systems security specialist with over 15 years of experience.
know_common_errors_justification: Common vulnerabilities such as those defined by OWASP are continuously checked for.
delivery_mitm_justification: Local CLI application - no MITM risk.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: This project is still in early stages of development.  This requirement will be re-evaluated at a later date.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Travis CI is used for this project.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
